entry.title: Improving my Hyprland WM setup
entry.summary: In my quest for building a perfect minimalist linux system, I decided to not use a waybar. I believe it wastes a lot of screen space and doesn't really give a minimalist vibe. While waybar does look pretty sexy, I think it also wastes a lot of space. Here is …
entry.content:
In my quest for building a perfect minimalist linux system, I decided to not use a waybar. I believe it wastes a lot of screen space and doesn't really give a minimalist vibe. While waybar does look pretty sexy, I think it also wastes a lot of space. Here is how my waybar looked like

You'll notice it has everything, a battery monitor (fish icon), cpu usage or memory usage stats, current time/date etc. It has a workspace switcher too, it was useful for me to know which is the current (1..9) workspace. It all looked cool, but I think these docks are inspired by mac, and I didn't like the idea of wasting screen space. Think about it when you're actually working on something, how often do you look on time or the topmost panels, I reckon rarely.

So I decided to ditch waybar completely from the configuration and instead use hyprexpo which is a hyprland plugin. I built the latest version of hyprland from git using yay and installed this hyprexpo plugin.

The next thing I missed was having a notification system. But dunst is a good way to achieve notifications too. Here is a sample notification and the entire configuration can be seen in my dotfiles. .

My first application during startup is wtfutil which will create a small dashboard on workspace 1, so I can read hackernews there, or check memory and cpu usage and also do stuff like keeping todo notes. It's very extensible and has its own configuration file.

Overall I'm quite satisfied with how my system looks now. youtube

entry.title: My thoughts after training for first day on ChessDojo
entry.summary: I practiced for almost 1.5 hours last night on the suggested weekly plan for my level on dojo. I had to spend 20 mins solving problems from the book by Lazslo Polgar on Mate in 2's, then focus 30 mins on reading the endgames part 1 by Jeremy Silman …
entry.content:
I practiced for almost 1.5 hours last night on the suggested weekly plan for my level on dojo. I had to spend 20 mins solving problems from the book by Lazslo Polgar on Mate in 2's, then focus 30 mins on reading the endgames part 1 by Jeremy Silman.

The endgames part 1 is meant for beginners, and I could say I could quickly skim through most of the pages as I'm already pretty familiar with Two Queen, Two Rooks, Queen King and Rook King endgames. So overall I think I will just finish part 1 today just to update progress on Dojo (there we have to keep a track of progress of how many pages you read and how much time you spent)

The interesting part for me however was the M2 exercises, I found out I was frequently misannotating the square names, or writing invalid moves sometimes by a queen. When you're playing most of the time online, the online board doesn't allow you to make invalid moves. I wrote a move where queen on h2 could move to Qa8, if you know anything about chess this is an invalid move. I need to work on following things from these mistakes about visualisation

  1. Knowing square names, the color of the square, and probably the squares adjacent to it.
  2. Knowing if a piece can reach from one square to other. For king it would be adjacent squares, for pawn a square or two above or en-passant or takes, same for other pieces. I think the trickiest would be a knight.

I have always realised that visualisation is an important skill, and that I should start working on it. It's a little daunting to imagine all the 64 squares in your head. I would probably start including some time to practice vision exercises on chess.com, and also holding a position in head and seeing where I was wrong.

I like the training program, it's intensive but as long as I keep finding out what I need to work on I dont mind paying 10 dollars a month.

I was taught guitar in an unconventional way. It's been a decade and now I look back and see the shortcomings of the way I was taught. I was never taught rhythm or music theory, instead the focus was to play songs by feeling it and only focus on the songs I enjoyed playing. Although it was enough to get started, I still struggle to read music theory or apply it in songs I play.

One example of it is learning 'Until I found you - Stephen Sanchez', the song uses a 6 beats in a bar style. I can of course play it without focussing on the rhythm and it doesn't sound bad either. But I will start focussing on learning rhythm the right way. Currently I'm struggling to maintain the count in my head, which is a little annoying. But hey, it's never easy to learn something new.

I will post the song cover on Youtube once I have learnt it properly.

entry.content:
The problem - Unique Binary Search Trees

Intuition

Having practiced a lot of dynamic programming problems in the past, I knew this can be solved with dynamic programming however I didn't get the intuition immediately for this. The intuition is pretty simple actually

All the elements on left of BST are always smaller than root, while on the elements on right are always greater (also note as nos are unique from 1.. N

Well I stated the obvious. Duh! Whenever we attempt a dynamic programming problem, we need to see 2 things recursive definition and overlapping subproblems. Let's start with observations.

  • Choose any root element x where x is in 1..N
  • By definition we know that fixing x on root, the numbers from 1..x-1 will lie on left, and nos from x+1 .. N will lie on right.
  • Now remember that 1..x-1 as well as x+1..N are consecutive.
  • If we already know the number of ways of to arrange k consecutive numbers in form of a valid binary search tree, we have already solved the problem.

Algorithm

Let's define dp[i] as number of ways to construct valid BSTs using i numbers. dp[0] = 1 because we know there is only way to create an empty subtree. Similarly we know dp[1] = 1
Take dp[2] as an example. If we fix 1 as root, then we already know that to create a valid BST of 0 nodes on left there are 1 ways, while to create a valid BST of 1 node on right there is 1 way. Similarly if we fix 2 as root, we know that on left there is 1 way to create a valid BST with one element and 1 way to create a valid BST with 0 elements on the right.

The function we get is like this

dp[i] = sum(dp[k-1] * dp[i-k]) from k = (1..i), k is where we incrementally fix the root element

The implementation like all the dp problems has very less code 

func numTrees(n int) int {
    var dp []int = make([]int, n+1)
    dp[0] = 1;

    for i := 1; i <= n; i++ {
        for r := 1; r <= i; r++ {
            dp[i] += dp[r - 1] * dp[i - r]
        }
    }

    return dp[n]
}

entry.content:
The problem - Inorder successor of node in a bst

I had attempted the problem before but I was too focussed on not using any global variables when implementing the solution. I guess being a senior developer we just try to avoid using global variables. To be honest, I did end up using the global variables at the end (I sucked up my pride!). I implemented two approaches here

Approach 1 (Naive Traversal)

The naive approach where you inorder traverse a BST and keep a track whether the target node has been found or not in a global variable and then find the next node which is greater than target node. You don't recurse the tree further if the in order successor is found. This solution beat ~53% of solutions at runtime. At worse case it will still be O(N) because it will traverse the entire tree at worst case. 

var foundTarget bool = false
var ans *TreeNode

func inOrderSuccessor(root *TreeNode, p *TreeNode) *TreeNode {
    inOrderHelper(root, p)
    return ans
}

func inOrderHelper(root *TreeNode, p *TreeNode) {
    if root == nil {
        return
    }

    if !foundTarget && ans == nil {
        inOrderSuccessor(root.Left, p)
    }

    if root.Val == p.Val {
        foundTarget = true
    }

    if foundTarget && root.Val > p.Val {
        ans = root
    }

    if !foundTarget && ans == nil {
        inOrderHelper(root.Right, p)
    }
}

Approach 2

The second approach was a little trick and even though it may seem like an overkill I am still glad I attempted it this way as I really thought out of my comfort zone

I picked up the trick from problem validating a binary search tree. You maintain a low & high variables and don't recurse the subtrees where you know solution can't exist. Although now I realize that maintaining the high and low variables was not required, but it still prunes the left subtree where we know an inorder successor can't exist.

For eg see the below image where if we are searching for 13 as target node we can prune the subtree marked in red entirely. This solution was ~93% faster than other solutions which makes sense because we don't explore left subtree in some cases

var foundP bool
var answer *TreeNode

func inorderSuccessor(root *TreeNode, p *TreeNode) *TreeNode {
    foundP = false
    answer = nil
    inorderHelper(root, p, math.MinInt32, math.MaxInt32)
    return answer
}

func inorderHelper(root *TreeNode, p *TreeNode, low, high int) {
    if root == nil {
        return
    }

    // we are iterating a subtree at root which has all the values
    // lower than p.Val so no point in iterating this subtree and return
    if p.Val > high {
        return
    }

    // left
    if answer == nil {
        inorderHelper(root.Left, p, low, root.Val)
    }

    // root
    if root.Val == p.Val {
        foundP = true
    }

    if foundP && answer == nil && root.Val > p.Val {
        answer = root
        return
    }

    // right
    if answer == nil {
        inorderHelper(root.Right, p, root.Val, high)
    }
}

Learnings

I'm not going to write the original solution mentioned in the editorial, the solution they have mentioned is beautiful. Just as a hint to my future self remember that the trees can be traversed iteratively as well (especially binary search trees). Also iterative solutions will have a benefit of not having a global variable (to satisfy my clean code thought process) and

the main point being you can store solutions while iterating and start optimising when you store something in an iterative solution, i.e you don't have to wait for a recursion to end. I quite enjoyed solving this problem.

entry.summary:
The problem - Closest Binary Search Tree Value

While the problem itself isn't very difficult, there is a small catch I thought that any traversals should work for this, however there is a minor detail which I missed, in case there are multiple solutions we should print the smallest value. This …
entry.content:
The problem - Closest Binary Search Tree Value

While the problem itself isn't very difficult, there is a small catch I thought that any traversals should work for this, however there is a minor detail which I missed, in case there are multiple solutions we should print the smallest value. This means it is better to traverse in an in-order traversal. A rather good problem would be the hard version of the problem which I believe requires implementing some sort of heap and passing it across the recursion. I have no idea what would be the time complexity of such a solution. But I'll attempt that problem next.

For this problem I implemented it in a standard way, it was good to learn that in golang you can assign names to function return values, this makes code a little more readable. 

func closestValue(root *TreeNode, target float64) int {
    ans, _ := helper(root, target)
    return ans
}

func helper(root *TreeNode, target float64) (closestElement int, minValue float64) {
    if root == nil {
        return -1, math.MaxFloat64
    }

    closestElement = -1
    minValue = math.MaxFloat64

    if root.Left != nil {
        element, minimumLeft := helper(root.Left, target)
        if minimumLeft < minValue {
            minValue = minimumLeft
            closestElement = element
        }
    }

    if abs(float64(root.Val) - target) < minValue {
        minValue = abs(float64(root.Val) - target)
        closestElement = root.Val
    }

    if root.Right != nil {
        element, minimumRight := helper(root.Right, target)
        if minimumRight < minValue {
            minValue = minimumRight
            closestElement = element
        }
    }

    return closestElement, minValue
}

func abs(x float64) float64 {
    if x < 0 {
        return -x
    }

    return x
}

It also seems I have gotten slightly better at writing Golang syntax. It is taking me relatively less time to think and implement something

entry.title: Golang with LSP setup in neovim
entry.summary: I decided to setup LSP in neovim for Golang development. I had known about LSP's for a while and I think it is a step in the right direction. With abundance of text editors, it is essential that we give users the opportunity to setup their development environment. I have …
entry.content:
I decided to setup LSP in neovim for Golang development. I had known about LSP's for a while and I think it is a step in the right direction. With abundance of text editors, it is essential that we give users the opportunity to setup their development environment. I have never been a fan of IDE's. The only IDE I recommend is IntelliJIdea if you're doing Java development. I still feel most of the IDEs are super bloated and force the users to do things a certain way. I prefer having a fast and efficient development environment and I'm trying to create a development environment using vim. I agree you have similar capability in IDE's in form of plugins but somehow IDE's have always felt slow and use a lot of resources.

LSP is basically a language server, your editor becomes a client and you can interact with your server to execute commands and do things like code-completion, code search, reference search etc. In vim, you can create keybindings to invoke specific LSP actions. I am currently using neovim with lazy kickstart plugin to manage packages. It already came with Mason installed and all I had to do was install gopls language server for golang. The LSP server already starts itself and attaches itself to current buffer if you're editing a go file.

Currently I'm happy with the results and will tweak my environment more in some time. Here is a gif to see what I'm talking about completely managed from vim and NO MOUSE

It didn't even take me 30 mins to configure the same Qtile keybindings which I struggled for so long, audio and brightness for example. And the animations really are super smooth, and I don't need a separate window manager(Qtile) and compositor (picom).

The next step is to rice my waybar configuration, and make some tweaks to leverage my OLED screen even more. At 42% battery currently I can already get around 5h of backup. So using dark colors should optimise the battery usage a little more. Yes, it's not an ARM machine and it can't compete with macbooks but still for a x86 architecture machine, that's an insane amount of backup

Absolutely loving Hyprland, so far

entry.title: Implemented binary search trees in golang today
entry.summary: I've been skipping writing because I was rather drunk on weekends. Today I decided to implement binary search trees in golang, because I always struggle with binary search tree style questions during interviews (another nemesis of mine are arrays with greedy solutions). It's high time I start working on taking …
entry.content:
I've been skipping writing because I was rather drunk on weekends. Today I decided to implement binary search trees in golang, because I always struggle with binary search tree style questions during interviews (another nemesis of mine are arrays with greedy solutions). It's high time I start working on taking down my nemesis, chuckes!

So, because I'm new to Golang, and pointers in it, I wanted to implement a simple binary search tree and in-order/sorted order traversal in it. Let's jump right into the code.

The node definition of BST looks like this. 

type Node struct {
    left *Node
    right *Node
    val int64
}

In fact, it's not very different from C style pointers and structs that I'm already used to when I learnt them in college. Next we needed to implement two functions

  • To implement the addNode function to add new nodes to a binary search tree, which always returns the root pointer.
  • To implement an inOrder traversal function left -> root -> right

Alright so implmentation is like this 

func addNode(root *Node, val int64) *Node {
    if root == nil {
        root = &Node{val: val}
    } else if root.val < val {
        root.right = addNode(root.right, val)
    } else {
        root.left = addNode(root.left, val)
    }

    return root
}


func traverseInOrder(root *Node) {

    if root == nil {
        return
    }

    if root.left != nil {
        traverseInOrder(root.left)
    }

    fmt.Printf("%d\n", root.val)

    if root.right != nil {
        traverseInOrder(root.right)
    }
}

Now I knew the functions looked correct, but I decided run a large number of auto generated test cases. The next step was to modify the traverseInOrder function to a function which returns a slice of integers, so I updated it to return []int64 instead 

func traverseInOrderModified(root *Node) []int64 {
    output := make([]int64, 0)
    if root == nil {
        return output
    }

    if root.left != nil {
        output = traverseInOrderModified(root.left)
    }

    output = append(output, root.val)

    if root.right != nil {
        output = append(output, traverseInOrderModified(root.right)...)  // notice the variadic function "..." which unpacks the slice
    }

    return output
}

To generate test cases and do the sorting and verification I wrote a helper function and in this way, got to learn a little more about sort package in golang, and copy function, also how to compare two slices using reflect.DeepEqual I also learnt that by default sort.Ints([]int) is available in the standard library and doesn't require imports. But if you want to sort []int64 then you need to implement some custom function. (Due to lack of knowledge I don't know what the helper function is called yet, I'm sure there is some term for it, like comparators in Java). Anyway here are the functions I wrote 

func generateRandomInt64Slice(min int64, max int64) []int64 {
  // Initialize the slice with length 100
  slice := make([]int64, 100)

  // Seed the random number generator (optional for better randomness)
  rand.Seed(time.Now().UnixNano())

  // Fill the slice with random int64 values within the specified range
  for i := range slice {
    // Generate a random int64 within the range [min, max)
    value := rand.Int63n(max - min) + min
    slice[i] = value
  }

  return slice
}

/* We generate a set of random numbers using generateRandomInt64Slice function and then create a BST and perform our inorder traversal
   If the result is same as sort we return true, otherwise false */
func generateBstAndValidateInOrderSortedTraversal() bool {
    input := generateRandomInt64Slice(10, 1000)
    expected := make([]int64, len(input))
    copy(expected, input)

    sort.Slice(expected, func(i, j int) bool {
        return expected[i] < expected[j]
    })

    //fmt.Println("Input: ", input) 
    //fmt.Println("Expected: ", expected)

    // generate BST
    var root *Node
    for _, val := range(input) {
        root = addNode(root, val) 
    }

    // store actual result
    actual := traverseInOrderModified(root)
    //fmt.Println("Actual: ", actual)

    return reflect.DeepEqual(expected, actual)
}

Now for the final part, I implemented go-routines and channels to collect the results. I expected some improvement for an implementation which parallizes 10000 test cases (and I actually timed the results using time shell command). However, it seemed to run slower than a simple for-loop for 100000 test cases. Probably, because the underlying concurrency model is not good. I simply threw away all the executions into a goroutine.

A better concurrent approach probably would be to isolate generation of test cases at once in 1 goroutine, then using multiple go-routines to split the task of creating bsts, then finally one go routine to validate the result. This is all currently a hypothesis, but I would love to experiment it over the weekend and go over Rob Pike's actual concurrency videos again.

Anyway here's the method which evaluates the correctness of my BST implementation and traversal function 

func main() {

    //fmt.Println("Matches: ", generateBstAndValidateInOrderSortedTraversal())
    const numTestCases = 100000
    results := make(chan bool, numTestCases)

    for i := 0; i < numTestCases; i++ {
        go func (caseNum int) {
            results <- generateBstAndValidateInOrderSortedTraversal()
        }(i)
    }

    successfullyValidatedCases := 0

    for i := 0; i < numTestCases; i++ {
        result := <- results
        if result {
            successfullyValidatedCases++
        }
    }

    fmt.Println("Successfully validated cases", successfullyValidatedCases)
}

I must say I'm finally enjoying programming again, now that I started learning golang. I think I got lost some part of myself chasing meaningless things for the last 5-6 years and forgot the joy of programming and exploring things. I'm sure you will have plenty of good topics to read about in upcoming posts

entry.title: external monitor setup with qtile, x11 on arch linux
entry.summary: I was thinking of how to use an external monitor in the vertical setup, although I was able to achieve the intented setup a little bit, I'm still not sure how I am going to use it Haha. But I also learnt a lot about Qtile api and how things …
entry.content:
I was thinking of how to use an external monitor in the vertical setup, although I was able to achieve the intented setup a little bit, I'm still not sure how I am going to use it Haha. But I also learnt a lot about Qtile api and how things work on X11.

So to achieve this setup, first I needed to use xrandr to achieve a vertical orientation of external monitor to the right of my laptop. To generate a script with the orientation I used arandr which is a GUI tool and can generate the xrandr script to initialize the external monitor.arandr generated the below script, and you can see how HDMI-1 is rotated right and the exact position of monitor 

1
2
#!/bin/sh
xrandr --output eDP-1 --primary --mode 2880x1800 --pos 0x0 --rotate normal --output HDMI-1 --mode 1920x1080 --pos 2927x0 --rotate right --output DP-1 --off --output DP-2 --off

Next step was configuring Qtile window manager, which was a little tricky. Basically I needed Qtile to do 3 things

  • Have 3 groups 7, 8, 9 on the new monitor, while group 1..6 should stay on laptop screen
  • Seamlessly able to switch groups without losing the focus on any screen. For eg - if I have a terminal opened on group 1 (laptop screen), and a browser opened on group 7 (external monitor), then switching to group 7, should not change the content of group1 in any way.

I had to hack and wander around a lot but I was able to achieve this with following configs 

groupbox1 = widget.GroupBox(visible_groups=['1', '2', '3', '4', '5', '6', '7', '8', '9'], highlight_method = "block", padding_x=5, fontsize=25)
groupbox2 = widget.GroupBox(visible_groups=['7', '8', '9'], highlight_method = "block", padding_x=5, fontsize=25)

@hook.subscribe.screens_reconfigured
async def _():
    if len(qtile.screens) > 1:
        groupbox1.visible_groups = ['1', '2', '3', '4', '5', '6']
    else:
        groupbox1.visible_groups = ['1', '2', '3', '4', '5', '6', '7', '8', '9']
    if hasattr(groupbox1, 'bar'):
        groupbox1.bar.draw()

This piece of code defines the groups and hooks I needed to use. The qtile hook screens_reconfigured gets invoked whenever there is a change in xrandr output.

Notice the multiple groupboxes, these are defined so that when if only laptop screen is active we show all the groups, otherwise we split groups between laptop and monitor.

The screen section of config get updated to something like this 

Screen(
    top=bar.Bar(
        [
            groupbox1,
            .....
            //rest of the widgets



),

Screen(
    top=bar.Bar(
        [
            groupbox2,
            #widget.GroupBox(highlight_method = "block", padding_x=5, fontsize=25, visible_groups=['7', '8', '9']),
            widget.WindowName(fontsize=bar_font_size),
            widget.Clock(format="%a %I:%M %p", fontsize=bar_font_size)
        ],
        35,
        margin=[15, 20, 10, 20],
        #border_width=[2, 0, 2, 0],  # Draw top and bottom borders
        #background="#00000000",
        #border_width=[2, 0, 2, 0],  # Draw top and bottom borders
        #border_color=["ff00ff", "000000", "ff00ff", "000000"]  # Borders are magenta
    ),
    wallpaper="/home/ryuk/Downloads/dragon-ball-kid-goku-moon-halloween-wallpaper-scaled.jpg",
    wallpaper_mode="fill",
    # You can uncomment this variable if you see that on X11 floating resize/moving is laggy
    # By default we handle these events delayed to already improve performance, however your system might still be struggling
    # This variable is set to None (no cap) by default, but you can set it to 60 to indicate that you limit it to 60 events per second
    # x11_drag_polling_rate = 60,
),

Notice now we have 2 screens in config, and the second screen also takes a wallpaper parameter to automatically use a vertical monitor when it is connected and set the wallpaper.

The real magic of switching however happens with below keybindings I use for Qtile, they check for available screens and if the length of screens list is greater than 1, then switching works

def go_to_group(name: str):
    def _inner(qtile):
        if len(qtile.screens) == 1:
            qtile.groups_map[name].toscreen()
            return

        if name in '123':
            qtile.focus_screen(0)
            qtile.groups_map[name].toscreen()
        else:
            qtile.focus_screen(1)
            qtile.groups_map[name].toscreen()

    return _inner

def go_to_group_and_move_window(name: str):
    def _inner(qtile):
        if len(qtile.screens) == 1:
            qtile.current_window.togroup(name, switch_group=True)
            return

        if name in "123":
            qtile.current_window.togroup(name, switch_group=False)
            qtile.focus_screen(0)
            qtile.groups_map[name].toscreen()
        else:
            qtile.current_window.togroup(name, switch_group=False)
            qtile.focus_screen(1)
            qtile.groups_map[name].toscreen()

    return _inner

for i in groups:
    keys.extend(
        [
            # mod1 + group number = switch to group
            Key(
                [mod],
                i.name,
                lazy.function(go_to_group(i.name)),
                desc="Switch to group {}".format(i.name),
            ),
            # mod1 + shift + group number = switch to & move focused window to group
            Key(
                [mod, "shift"],
                i.name,
                lazy.function(go_to_group_and_move_window(i.name)),
                desc="Switch to & move focused window to group {}".format(i.name),
            )            # Or, use below if you prefer not to switch to that group.
            # # mod1 + shift + group number = move focused window to group
            # Key([mod, "shift"], i.name, lazy.window.togroup(i.name),
            #     desc="move focused window to group {}".format(i.name)),
        ]
    )

entry.content:
Having installed arch linux again, I am going back to vim style of editing the files. I use neovim specifically and recently I struggled with how to yank lines from your editor to a global clipboard. This is needed at times when you want to copy something from your editor like code for eg to a clipboard and paste it in browser.

I didn't knew that anything which is yanked or deleted in vim is stored into a register. To see the current content of all the registers, run :reg in command mode.

How to copy

  • First you have to go into visual mode in vim using Shift + V then you can select the lines you want to copy, if it is the entire thing to end of file then you can also press G.

  • Once the lines are selected the next step is to yank them into a system clipboard register. In case of system clipboard in linux the register is +. So to copy into clipboard we simply do it using "+y to yank the selected lines in visual mode

I am really curious about the functionalities of registers in vim now. After all it's called one of the most powerful editors with a high learning curve due to a reason. Haha

entry.content:
I managed to solve 3 simple implementation problems today, all 3 related to string manipulation of some kind. I used the most brute force way to solve the problems, however I should check out the leetcode pattern for string problems. The thing is, I didn't want to go too quickly into the solution pattern as I am learning the implementation and I'm sure such problems will be arriving soon.

Anyway here's the code for all the problems and the links to the problem, so that I can review the syntax used.

Problem1

func strStr(haystack string, needle string) int {

    for i := 0; i < len(haystack); i++ {
        if haystack[i] == needle[0] {
            if isSubstring(i, haystack, needle) == true {
                return i
            }
        }
    }

    return -1
}

func isSubstring(startIdx int, haystack string, needle string) bool {
    i := 0
    for startIdx < len(haystack) && i < len(needle) && haystack[startIdx] == needle[i] {
        i = i + 1
        startIdx = startIdx + 1
    }

    if i == len(needle) {
        return true
    }

    return false
}

Problem2

func isAnagram(s string, t string) bool {
    smap, tmap := make(map[byte]int), make(map[byte]int)

    for i:= 0; i < len(s); i++ {
        smap[s[i]]++
    }

    for i:= 0; i < len(t); i++ {
        tmap[t[i]]++
    }


    for key, val := range smap {
        if tmap[key] != val {
            return false
        }
    }

    for key, val := range tmap {
        if smap[key] != val {
            return false
        }
    }

    return true
}

Problem3

func repeatedSubstringPattern(s string) bool {
    for chainLength:= 1; chainLength <= len(s)/2; chainLength++ {
        if doesChainRepeat(chainLength, s) {
            fmt.Println("Found chain of length ", chainLength)
            return true
        }
    }

    return false
}

func doesChainRepeat(chainLength int, s string) bool {
    for startIdxOne:= chainLength; startIdxOne < len(s); startIdxOne = startIdxOne + chainLength {
        fmt.Printf("Chain Length: %d, startIdxOne: %d\n", chainLength, startIdxOne)
        i,j := 0, startIdxOne
        for ; i < chainLength && j < len(s); i,j = i+1, j+1 {
            if (s[i] != s[j]) {
                return false
            }
        }

        if (i != chainLength) {
            return false
        }
    }

    return true
}

entry.content:
I have started practicing the leetcode Programming Skills study plan. To grasp a language quickly, it has progressive set of exercises. I started with a problem where you were given two strings and you had to merge them alternatively, eg - word1 - "Hello" and word2 - "World" then the function should return a concatenated string "HWeolrllod".

Here is the code which I came up with 

package main

import "fmt"

func main() {
    const (
        word1 = "Hello"
        word2 = "World"
    )

    fmt.Println(mergeStringsAlternatively(word1, word2))
}

func mergeStringsAlternatively(word1 string, word2 string) string {

    word1Len := len(word1)
    word2Len := len(word2)

    var mergedString string
    i, j := 0, 0

    for ; i < word1Len && j < word2Len; i, j = i+1, j+1 {
        mergedString += string(word1[i])
        mergedString += string(word2[j])

    }

    for ; i < word1Len; i++ {
        mergedString += string(word1[i])
    }

    for ; j < word2Len; j++ {
        mergedString += string(word2[j])
    }

    return mergedString
}

While doing the problem I found out there are some really cool ways to use for in Golang. As I come from C like languages and Java background a while loop has been pretty much ingrained into my body. I do think Go has done a remarkable job capturing the essence of while loops with a for style loop.

Notice how the declaration can be done independently outside of for construct, and how both variables i,j can be incremented together. Definitely impressed with the construct. string on the other hand gave me pretty much a headache. I think the problem is that I started asking Gemini. rune, byte, slice of runes and a lot of things I tried resulted in failure. I'm sure this will get easier with time as I learn the internals, but for the time I will still keep my opinion that strings in golang are hell.

entry.title: Creating 2-D arrays in golang
entry.content:
I was doing leetcode problems because being prepared doesn't harm anyone, haha, and I'm also trying to learn golang in parallel. Going through the basic syntax currently and a lot of time scenarios arise where you have to initialise a 2-D array eg- graphs, or for dynamic programming problems. Here we use built-in make function to create a slice in golang. So this implementation is a slice of slices. I read there is other way of creating 2D arrays as well but I'll explore that later as this seems simpler to me. 

package main

import "fmt"

func main() {
    const columns = 5;
    const rows = 6;

    var multiDimensionalArray [][]int = make([][]int, rows);
    for i := 0; i < rows; i++ {
        multiDimensionalArray[i] = make([]int, columns);
    }

    // Accessing rows and columns
    for i := 0; i < rows; i++ {
        for j := 0; j < columns; j++ {
            multiDimensionalArray[i][j] = 1;
        }
    }

    fmt.Println(multiDimensionalArray);

}
